title-group.article-title: Synergistic effect of lycopene and tocopherol against oxidative stress and mammary tumorigenesis induced by 7,12-dimethyl[a]benzanthracene in female rats

article-meta.aff: 1Biochemistry Department, King Abdul-Aziz University, KSA, Jeddah

author-notes.corresp: Said S Moselhy, Faculty of Science, Ain Shams University, Cairo 22015, Egypt. Email: moselhy6@hotmail.com

abstract.p: Breast cancer is one of the most serious problems in oncology. We investigated the antitumor potential of lycopene (Lyco) alone or combined with tocopherol (Lyco + Toco) for 90 days against a single oral dose of (50 mg/kg body weight) 7,12-dimethyl[a]benzanthracene (DMBA)-induced oxidative stress and mammary carcinogenesis in female rats. The treatment protocol started from the day immediately after DMBA administration. Results obtained indicated that there was a significant elevation in the levels of malondialdehyde (MDA) and nitric oxide (NO) in serum and breast tissues of DMBA-injected rats. The combined treatment (Lyco + Toco) group showed a potential reduction of these parameters more than Lyco alone group. The activities of superoxide dismutase, catalase, and glutathione peroxidase were found to be significantly higher when compared to rats treated with Lyco alone. In DMBA group, a positive significant correlation between NO and MDA (r = 0.92) was observed. Histopathological examination revealed the formation of tumor and angiogenesis in DMBA-induced rats and these abnormal changes were ameliorated by combined treatment with Lyco + Toco. In conclusion, these results suggested that supplementation of diet with Lyco and Toco provided antioxidant defense, with strong chemopreventive activity against DMBA-induced mammary tumors.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Breast cancer is one of the most common cancers in women. Worldwide, it is the second most common type of cancer after lung cancer (World Health Organization, 2003) and the fifth most common cause of cancer death (World Health Organization, 2006). Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are involved in a variety of important pathophysiological conditions including mutagenesis and carcinogenesis (Aruoma, 1994; Cerutti, 1985). Oxidative stress has the potential to cause cellular DNA damage, lipid peroxidation, and membrane disruption (Gilbert and Colton, 1999). Human body is equipped with various antioxidants such as superoxide dismutase (SOD), glutathione peroxidase (GPx), catalase (CAT), glutathione (GSH), ascorbic acid (vitamin C), α-tocopherol (vitamin E), and so on, which can counteract the deleterious action of ROS and protect from cellular and molecular damage (Jagetia and Rao, 2006).

Bioactive compounds from plant origin have the potential to subside the biochemical imbalances induced by various toxins associated with free radicals. They provide protection without causing any side effects and therefore, development of drugs from plant products is desired. For that account natural antioxidants from plant sources have been viewed as promising therapeutic drugs (Vijayavel et al., 2006).

Specific nutrients rich in fruits and vegetables, including carotenoids, may play a role in cancer prevention (Clinton, 1998). Lycopene, the pigment principally responsible for the characteristic deep-red color of ripe tomato fruits and tomato products, has received much attention in recent years because of its beneficial effect in the treatment of diseases (Rao and Agarwal, 1999). It was demonstrated that lycopene provided the best protection against singlet oxygen-induced cell damage (Joseph et al., 2001).

Lycopene has been shown to have strong antioxidant properties relative to other carotenoids (Vijayavel et al., 2006). Recently, lycopene has garnered specific attention over other carotenoids for its potential role in cancer prevention (Sesso, et al. 2005). Epidemiologic studies revealed that, lycopene may increasingly be identified as sharing inverse relationships to cancer with other common carotenoids or as being the only carotenoid to show such an association (Gerster, 1997).

Lycopene in human plasma has a half-life of about 2–3 days (Clinton, 1998). Only a few metabolites, such as 5,6-dihydroxy-5,6-dihydro lycopene, have been detected in human plasma (Rao and Agarwal, 1999). Owing to its lipophilic nature, lycopene was found in serum low-density lipoprotein (LDL) and very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) fractions and not in high-density lipoprotein (HDL) (Fuhramn et al., 1997).

α-Tocopherol is a major lipid-soluble antioxidant vitamin that acts as a free radical scavenger present as an integral component in cellular membranes and having important biological functions (Burton, 1994). This vitamin is known to protect cellular membranes from oxidative damage and lipid peroxidation (Machlin and Bendich, 1987). Supplementation of this antioxidant is also reported to decrease oxidative DNA damage (Carpenter, 1991). α-Tocopherol has been considered to be one of the potential chemopreventive agents for cancer. Experimental studies have revealed the protective effects of this vitamin against the development of sarcomas and carcinomas at different sites. Research on the protective effect of α-tocopherol on carcinogenesis, some experimental studies and human trials are underway (Duthe et al., 1996).

The primary mechanism by which carotenoids and tocopherols are proposed to prevent cancer is through their antioxidant properties (Gilbert and Colton, 1999). Our previous study concluded that lycopene-supplemented diet with melatonin provided antioxidant defense, with strong chemopreventive activity against DMBA-induced mammary tumors (Moselhy and Almslmani, 2008).

The goal of this study was to evaluate the effect of lycopene (Lyco) alone or combined with tocopherol (Lyco + Toco) in inhibiting the oxidative stress and carcinogenic effect of DMBA-induced mammary cancer in rats.

sec.title: Experimental animals
sec.p: The experimental protocol was approved by the animal care committee of King Abdul-Aziz University.

Sixty female adult Sprague Dawley rats, weighing 80–100 g, were purchased from colony of laboratory animals from the King Fahd Medical Research Center, Jeddah, KSA. The rats were housed in steel mesh cages and acclimatized for a 1-week period on commercial pellet diet and drinking water ad libitum. Rats were maintained under standard animal house conditions (12:12 h light–dark and 22°C temperature). Rats were randomly divided into 4 groups (15 rats per group), group I: (control). Rats of groups II, III, and IV were administrated intragastrically with a single dose of (50 mg/kg BW) 7,12-dimethyl[a]benzanthracene (DMBA, Sigma Chemicals, St Louis, MO, USA). DBMA was dissolved in corn oil and given in a volume of 1 ml (Machlin and Bendich, 1987). On the day after DMBA administration, rats in group III were fed on diet supplemented with lycopene (50 mg/kg of diet) (Henry and Narendra, 2006), and rats in group IV were supplemented with lycopene injected orally a dose of 100 mg Toco/kg BW (Das, 1994). Rats were palpated weekly for tumor appearance. At the end of the experiment (90 days), the rats were killed under anesthesia with diethylether. Blood and breast were collected. Blood was left without anticoagulant for serum separation. Serum and tissues were stored at −20°C until analysis. A part of tissues were collected in 10% formalin for histopathological examination.
The constituents of standard diet are protein (17%), oil (3.5%), fiber (8.5%), moisture (14%), digestible energy (12%), vitamins mixture (1%), and minerals mixture (2.5%).

sec.title: Nitric oxide measurement
sec.p: Serum and tissue nitrite and nitrate concentrations were measured by modified micro-assay according to the method of Vodovotz (1996). Briefly, nitrate was reduced to nitrite by cadmium. Nitrite was measured by Griess reaction.

sec.title: Malondialdhyde measurement
sec.p: Serum and tissues malondialdehyde (MDA) was measured by thiobarbituric acid method as described by Zima et al. (1995). The reaction mixture in a total volume of 10 ml containing 0.2 ml of tissue homogenate or serum, 0.2 ml of 8.1% sodium dodecyl sulfate, 1.5 ml of 20% acetic acid, 1.5 ml of distilled water, and 5 ml of n-butanol and pyridine mixture were heated at 95°C for 60 minutes. The pink-colored chromogen formed by the reaction of 2-thiobarbituric acid with the breakdown products of MDA were read at 535 nm.

sec.title: Assay of SOD activity
sec.p: The SOD activity was determined by the nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) reduction method (Flohe and Otting, 1984). A 0.1 ml of tissue supernatant was added to a reaction mixture containing 0.1 mM EDTA (200 μl), 0.12 mM riboflavin (50 μl), and 0.6 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.8) in a final volume of 3 ml. The optical density was measured at 560 nm. The activity was expressed as U/min/mg protein.

sec.title: Assay of CAT activity
sec.p: Catalase activity was determined according to the method Claiborne (1985). The reaction mixture (2 ml) contained 1.95 ml of 10 mM hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) in 60 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7.0). The reaction was started by adding 0.5 ml of tissue supernatant and the absorbance reading was taken at 240 nm after 3 minutes. Phosphate-buffered saline (60 mM, pH 7.0) was used as a reference. The data are expressed as μmol H2O2 consumed/min/mg protein.

sec.title: Assay of GPx activity
sec.p: Assay of GPx activity was based on the oxidation of GSH by cumene hydroperoxide. The activity of GPx was assayed by the method of Rotruck et al. (Ellman, 1959). The reaction mixture containing 0.2 ml of EDTA (0.8 mM, pH 7.0), 0.4 ml of phosphate buffer (10 mM), and 0.2 ml of tissue homogenate or serum were incubated with 0.1 M of H2O2 and 0.2 ml of GSH for 10 minutes. Oxidation of GSH by the enzyme was measured spectrophotometrically at 420 nm. The activity of GPx was expressed as μmol GSH oxidized/min/mg protein.

sec.title: Histopathological examination
sec.p: Mammary tissues were fixed in 10% buffered formalin, embedded in paraffin using a conventional automated system. The blocks were cut to obtain 5-μm thick sections and stained with hematoxylin–eosin (Costa et al., 2002). The image of serial paraffin sections of each tissue were captured by light microscopy (Olympus BX51, Hamburg, Germany).

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Data were presented as the mean ± SD. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Tukey multiple comparison method was carried out to compare the mean value of different groups using SPSS 7.5 student version. Comparisons were made between group I versus groups II, III, and IV and group II versus groups III and IV. The p value <0.05 was considered statistically significant in all cases. Correlation between variable data was determined by linear regression analysis.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The body weight (BW) and the protection percentage in rats receiving either Lyco individually or combined with Toco is shown in Table 1. The BW was significantly decreased in tumor-induced animals versus control (p < 0.01) (Table 1 ). Conversely, supplementation of Lyco + Toco increased the BW of rats treated with Lyco alone compared to the control group. It was found that protection against DMBA-induced carcinogenesis in rats receiving Lyco alone was 70%, while it was 85% in animals that received Lyco with Toco as compared with nontreated rats. In the DMBA group, 5 out of 15 rats died (2 after 5 days and 3 after 75 days). In Lyco-treated group, 3 out of 12 rats died and in combined (Lyco + Toco) treatment 2 out of 15 rats died. In the DMBA group, there was severe inflammatory reaction on submandibular skin and development of multiple masses involving the mammary gland tissues.

caption.p: Body weight and incidence of breast tumor in all studied groups (mean ± SD)

fn.p: DMBA: 7,12-dimethylbenz[a]anthracene, Lyco: lycopene, Toco: tocopherol, NS: nonsignificant.
aGroups II, III, and IV compared with control group I.
bGroups III and IV compared with control group II.

sec.p: Both MDA and nitric oxide (NO) levels in serum and breast tissues were increased statistically significantly in the rats with cancer; whereas, little reduction was found in the rats treated with Lyco, and much reduction in combined treatment (p < 0.01) as compared with nontreated rats (Table 2 ).

caption.p: Malondialdhyde (MDA) and nitric oxide (NO) levels in serum and tissues of all studied groups (mean ± SD)

fn.p: DMBA: 7,12-dimethylbenz[a]anthracene, Lyco: lycopene, Toco: tocopherol, NS: nonsignificant.
aGroups II, III, and IV compared with control group I.
bGroups III and IV compared with control group II.

sec.p: There was a significant elevation in the activities of SOD in the combined (Lyco + Toco) treatment group versus tumor-bearing rats compared to group treated with Lyco alone (Table 3 ). CAT activity was significantly (p < 0.05) lower in animals with breast cancer versus the control group. Moreover, higher CAT activity was recorded in groups treated with Lyco + Toco than Lyco alone versus nontreated rats. GPx activity was significantly (p < 0.01) high in the combined (Lyco + Toco) treatment group compared to the group of rats treated with than Lyco alone. The activity of GPx was reduced in tumor-bearing rats versus the normal group (Table 3).

caption.p: The activities of tissue superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), and glutathione peroxidase (GPx) of all studied groups (mean ± SD)

fn.p: DMBA: 7,12-dimethylbenz[a]anthracene, Lyco: lycopene, Toco: tocopherol, NS: nonsignificant.
aGroups II, III, and IV compared with control group I.
bGroups III and IV compared with control group II.

sec.title: Histological examination
sec.p: Histological examination revealed that DMBA induced invasive breast lesions compared with DMBA treated with Lyco and Toco. The mammary gland tissues in control group formed of an admixture of fibro fatty tissues and ductal structures showed development of carcinoma in DMBA injected group. This was evident by neovasularization, presence of uniformly malignant ductal epithelial cells growing in vague cribiform pattern, necrosis formation along the tumor, and cell destructions. DMBA group treated with Lyco showed absence of the malignant changes with normal appearance of ductal tissues, and treatment with Lyco + Toco resulted in complete disappearance of abnormal changes caused by DMBA.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: A new strategy was developed for antineoplastic and free radical scavenging properties of various phytotherapeutic origins (Ramar et al., 2006). The available semisynthetic anticancer drugs have more side effects and are cytotoxic to human beings. Since modern medicine has no effective cure for the malignant cancers and tumors, scientists are interested in finding a potent phototherapeutic agent with noncytotoxic properties.

The DMBA-induced mammary gland mimics some aspects of human disease and enables investigators to elucidate host factor influences on the initiation and promotion of breast cancer (Kaufmann et al., 2008). DMBA has been widely used as an animal model for the development of chemopreventive drugs to cure breast cancer in humans (Mehta, 2000). Data of the present study indicated that daily intake of Lyco alone or combined with Toco could prevent or delay the development of breast cancer in rat. The effects are highly significant, because fewer of the Lyco-supplemented animals (7 of12) developed tumor versus DMBA group and much lower (3 of 13) in combined treatment group. Also Lyco + Toco treatment decreases the number and size of tumors induced by the carcinogen (Table 1).

The DMBA requires metabolic activation by cytochrome P450 to form diol epoxide and other ROS that are known to increase intracellular oxidation (Guerin, 1978). Metabolism of DMBA by the mixed function oxidases system often results in the formation of oxyradicals ‘O2 ċ−, H2O2, ċOH,’ which bind covalently to nucleophilic sites on cellular macromolecules, thereby eliciting cancerous responses (Giri et al., 1995). The generation of ROS and the peroxidation of membrane lipids are well associated with the initiation of carcinogenesis affecting the normal biochemical process, which further leads to the reduction in BW (Davis and Kuttan, 2001). This is in accordance with our results which revealed a significant reduction in BW as a result of DMBA administration. Serum and tissue MDA and NO levels increased significantly in the rats with breast cancer; their levels showed little reduction in the groups treated with Lyco alone and much reduction when combined with Toco; it was near to the normal in the control group. The reduction in NO level in combined treatment may be due to the inhibition of NO synthase enzyme as described by Hussein et al. (2005). In the DMBA group, a negative significant correlation was found between weight and serum NO (r = −0.71), and a positive significant correlation was found between NO and MDA (r = 0.92).

Oxidative stress due to the generation of free radicals and/or decreased antioxidant level in the target cells and tissues have been suggested to play an important role in carcinogenesis (Huang et al., 1999). During cell membrane damage, various enzymes leak down to the circulatory fluid and their assessment in serum serves as markers in clinical studies. SOD is a major intracellular enzyme, which protects against oxygen free radicals by catalyzing the dismutation of superoxide free radical and anions to H2O2 and oxygen. Catalase is an enzyme which is present in most cells and which catalyses the decomposition of H2O2 to water and oxygen. GPx is an equally important antioxidant, which reacts with H2O2, thus preventing intracellular damage caused by the same (Cerutti et al., 1994; Gupta et al., 2004; Weydert et al., 2006).

Vitamin E has been reported to be one of the most potent free radical scavengers, which significantly reduce free radical-induced chemical damages to DNA and membrane lipids (Claycombe and Meydani, 2001). Vitamin E is lipophilic which has been found to scavenge various free radicals and effectively protect DNA and membranes against ionizing radiation (Kapoor et al., 2002).

The present study revealed that SOD activity was decreased in the animals with cancer, which may be due to altered antioxidant status caused by carcinogenesis. Decrease in CAT activity was measured in patients with breast cancer and benign breast disease conditions (Gonenc et al., 2006). This is in accordance with our results that indicate a decreased CAT in animals with cancer may be due to the utilization of antioxidant enzymes in the removal of H2O2 released. GPx is an important defense enzyme against oxidative damage and this in turn requires GSH as a cofactor. GPx catalyses the oxidation of GSH to GSSG at the expense of H2O2 (Cerutti et al., 1994). Decreased GPx activity was also observed in cancerous conditions (Bewick et al., 1987). Our findings agree well with this observation and also the activity of GPx significantly decreased in animals with cancer. CAT activity was significantly higher in the combination treatment group versus those treated with Lyco alone.

The combination treatment showed a significant reduction in tumors at the molecular level versus the cancer controls. Biochemical analysis revealed that combination treatment significantly inhibited lipid peroxidation, thus suggesting the antioxidant mechanism of Lyco when combined with Toco. The combination treatment may be useful in the prevention of breast cancer.

fn.p: The authors would like to thank Prof. Dr Taha Koumosani, head of biochemistry, Faculty of Science, KAU, Jeddah, KSA for kindly facilitating supplies for this work.
